Alright, here is my $.02 worth on how to interpret the "militia" clause of the Second Amendment:
 
 "A well regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed." 2nd. Amendment. 
 
 In short, I believe that our founding fathers feared a standing professional army, and this clause in the Amendment is a preamble asserting the belief that a standing professional army should be avoided as dangerous to individual liberty. Here is why I think this way:
 
 I believe we must first remember that our founders had witnessed their own government's use of a professional army to oppress them. T.J. wrote for them all when he drafted the Continental Congress' justification for a call to arms to fight their oppressors:
 
 "We are reduced to the alternative of choosing an unconditional submission to the tyranny of irritated ministers, or resistance by force. The latter is our choice. We have counted the cost of this contest, and find nothing so dreadful as voluntary slavery. Honor, justice, and humanity, forbid us tamely to surrender that freedom which we received from our gallant ancestors, and which our innocent posterity have a right to receive from us. We cannot endure the infamy and guilt of resigning succeeding generations to that wretchedness which inevitably awaits them, if we basely entail hereditary bondage upon them.
 Our cause is Just. Our Union is Perfect. Our internal resources are great, and, if necessary, foreign assistance is undoubtedly attainable. - We gratefully acknowledge, as signal instances of the Divine favor towards us, that his Providence would not permit us to be called into this severe controversy, until we were grown up to our present strength, had been previously exercised in warlike operation, and possessed of the means of defending ourselves. With hearts fortified with these animating reflections, we most solemnly, before God and the world, declare, that, exerting the utmost energy of those powers, which our beneficent Creator hath graciously bestowed upon us, the arms we have been compelled by our enemies to assume, we will, in defiance of every hazard, with unabating firmness and perseverance, employ for the preservation of our liberties; being with one mind resolved to die freemen rather than to live slaves.
 We fight not for glory or for conquest. We exhibit to mankind the remarkable spectacle of a people attacked by unprovoked enemies, without any imputation or even suspicion of offence. They boast of their privileges and civilization, and yet proffer no milder conditions than servitude or death.
 In our own native land, in defense of the freedom that is our birthright, and which we ever enjoyed till the late violation of it - for the protection of our property, acquired solely by the honest industry of our fore-fathers and ourselves, against violence actually offered, we have taken up arms. We shall lay them down when hostilities shall cease on the part of the aggressors, and all danger of their being renewed shall be removed, and not before."  
 Quote from the Declaration of the Causes and Necessity of Taking Up Arms, July 6, 1775. taken from Sources Of Our Liberties, American Bar Foundation, Richard L. Perry, editor, revised edition (William S. Hein & Co. 1990) beginning at p. 295.
 
 These are obviously strong words which reflect the severity of the crisis our founders found themselves in. I'll skip the war because we all know who won. But, having survived that trial of force with their own government's professional army, does anyone seriously suggest that our founders did not fear a repeat of the same if a standing army were raised in America's future? I believe they carried a healthy fear of a standing army with them when they sat down to frame their new governments, and you can see ample evidence of it in the various state constitutions. Here are just a few examples:
 
 "That a well-regulated militia, composed of the body of the people, trained to arms, is the proper, natural, and safe defense of a free state; that standing armies, in time of peace, should be avoided, as dangerous to liberty; and that in all cases the military should be under strict subordination to, and governed by, the civil power."  From the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Virginia, June 6, 1776.
 
 "That the people have a right to bear arms for the defense of themselves and the state; And as standing armies in the time of peace are dangerous to liberty, they ought not to be kept up; And that the military should be kept under strict subordination to, and governed by, the civil power."  From the Constitution of the state of Pennsylvania, August 16, 1776.
 
 "That a well regulated militia is the proper, natural and safe defense of a free government. That standing armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought to be under strict subordination to and governed by the civil power."  From the Constitution of the state of Delaware, September 11, 1776.
 
 "That the people have a right to keep and bear arms, that a well regulated militia, including the body of the people capable of bearing arms, is the proper, natural, and safe defense of a free state."  From the Constitution of the state of New York (sorry, the year escapes me, but I know it predated the BoR)
 
 [Incidentally, here lies a tremendous problem for the collective right theory. If the language of the Second Amendment was merely designed to protect the "right" of the states to equip a state militia free from federal governmental interference, then why were these provisions written into the various state constitutions? At the time the state constitutions were drafted and ratified the only parties to these social compacts were the state and its citizens. These provisions clearly recognize an individual liberty interest which needed protection from tyrannical state governmental encroachment. If our founding fathers felt that they needed the individual right to protect them from their state governments, then why wouldn't they want they want the same protection from the new federal government's ability to abuse its power?] 
 
 In any event I believe it is easy to see that this is where the language "well regulated militia" comes from. But what was the militia of the times? How were they armed?
 
 "The signification attributed to the term Militia appears from the debates in the Convention, the history and legislation of the Colonies and the States, and the writings of approved commentators. These show plainly enough that the militia comprised all males physically capable of acting in concert for the common defense. "A body of citizens enrolled for military discipline." And further, that ordinarily when called for service these men were expected to appear bearing arms supplied by themselves and of a kind in common use at the time."  U.S. v. Miller, 307 U.S. 174, 179 (1939).
 
 Why then a militia composed of men bearing private arms? I believe the system was designed to reduce, as much as possible, the need to maintain the much feared professional army. Additionally, our founders felt that maintaining these arms in private hands deterred tyranny. See, for example, the following:
 
 "If the citizens have these arms in their hands, they are prepared in the best possible manner to repel any encroachments upon their rights."  Aymette v. State, 2 Hump. (21 Tenn.) 154, 158 (1840). Significant because it was cited with approval by SCOTUS in U.S. v. Miller, Miller at p. 178. (and people still think Miller was a "collective" right opinion)
 
 "It has been asserted by the most respectable writers upon government, that a well-regulated militia, composed of the yeomanry of the country, have ever been considered as the bulwark of a free people. Tyrants have never placed any confidence on a militia composed of freemen."  John DeWitt, The Anti-Federalist Papers, p. 75 (M. Borden ed. 1965)
 
 "Little more can reasonably be aimed at with respect to the people at large than to have them properly armed and equipped. . . .This will not only lessen the call for military establishments, but if circumstances should at any time oblige the government to form an army of any magnitude that army can never be formidable to the liberties of the people while there is a large body of citizens, little if any inferior to them in discipline and the use of arms, who stand ready to defend their rights and those of their fellow citizens."  Alexander Hamilton, The Federalist Papers #29, reprinted at page 185 in The Federalist Papers, Mentor Books, 1969, edited by Clinton Rossiter.
 
 "Before a standing army can rule, the people must be disarmed; as they are in almost every kingdom of Europe. The supreme power in America cannot enforce unjust laws by the sword; because the whole body of the people are armed, and constitute a force superior to any bands of regular troops that can be, on any pretense, raised in the United States. A military force, at the command of Congress, can execute no laws, but such as the people perceive to be just and constitutional; for they will possess the power, and jealousy will instantly inspire the inclination, to resist the execution of a law which appears to them unjust and oppressive."  Noah Webster, "An Examination into the Leading Principles of the Federal Constitution" (1787) in Pamphlets on the Constitution of the United States (P. Ford, 1888).
 
 "A militia, when properly formed, are in fact the people themselves, and render regular troops in a great measure unnecessary. . . .the constitution ought to secure a genuine and guard against a select militia. . .and include. . .all men capable of bearing arms. . . . But, say gentlemen, the general militia are for the most part employed at home in their private concerns, cannot well be called out, or be depended upon; that we must have a select militia. . . .[of the select militia] These Corps, not much unlike regular troops, well ever produce an inattention to the general militia. . .whereas, to preserve liberty, it is essential that the whole body of the people always possess arms, and be taught alike, especially when young, how to use them. . . .The mind that aims at a select militia, must be influenced by a truly anti-republican principle; and when we see many men disposed to practice upon it, whenever they can prevail, no wonder true republicans are for carefully guarding against it."  Richard Henry Lee, Additional Letters from the Federal Farmer, p. 169-170 (1788)
 
 Now I think we come to the reason for inclusion of the Second Amendment in the BoR. The individual citizen's RKBA was widely accepted as necessary to prevent the rise of domestic tyranny at the state level. But the newly proposed federal constitution did not prohibit a future tyrannical federal government from totally disarming the individual citizen's ability to "appear bearing arms supplied by themselves" as a state militia to resist federal oppression. Remember Patrick Henry's complaint of a federal constitution without a BoR:
 
 "My great objection to this Government is, that it does not leave us the means of defending our rights; or, of waging war against tyrants...."
 "The Honorable Gentleman who presides, told us, that to prevent abuses in our Government, we will assemble in Convention, recall our delegated powers, and punish our servants for abusing the trust reposed in them. Oh, Sir, we should have fine times indeed, if to punish tyrants, it were only sufficient to assemble the people. Your arms wherewith you could defend yourselves, are gone. . . . Did you ever read of any revolution in any nation, brought about by the punishment of those in power, inflicted by those who had no power at all? You read of a riot act in a country which is called one of the freest in the world, where a few neighbors cannot assemble without the risk of being shot by hired soldiery, the engines of despotism. We may see such an act in America. A standing army we shall have also, to execute the execrable commands of tyranny: And how are you to punish them? Will you order them to be punished? Who shall obey these orders? Will your Mace-bearer be a match for a disciplined regiment? In what situation are we to be? . . . .What resistance could be made? The attempt would be madness."  Patrick Henry, Speeches of June 5 and 7, 1788, before the Virginia Ratifying Convention, reprinted in The Anti-Federalist Papers and the Constitutional Convention Debates, pages 199-216, Mentor Books, 1986, edited by Ralph Ketchum.
 
 So then, when we finally got our BoR, who did James Madison use to support his push for ratification? His good friend and fellow federalist, Tench Coxe. Coxe had already written an eloquent response to the anti-federalist's fears of the federal government's ability to neuter the state militias by disarming the people:
 
 "My friends and countrymen, it is not so, for the powers of the sword are in the hands of the yeomanry of America from sixteen to sixty. The militia of these free commonwealths, entitled and accustomed to their arms, when compared with any possible army, must be tremendous and irresistible. Who are the militia? Are they not ourselves? Is it feared, then, that we shall turn our arms each man against his own bosom? Congress shall have no power to disarm the militia. Their swords and every other terrible implement of the soldier, are the birth-right of an American ....[T]he unlimited power of the sword is not in the hands of either the federal or the state governments, but where I trust in God it will ever remain, in the hands of the People."  Tench Coxe, Pennsylvania Gazette, Feb. 20, 1788.
 
 To assist his friend's push for adoption of the BoR, Coxe wrote a treatise entitled Remarks on the First Part of the Amendments to the Federal Constitution. In his Remarks, Coxe described the Second Amendment as follows:
 
 "As civil rulers, not having their duty to the people duly before them, may attempt to tyrannize, and as the military forces which must be occasionally raised to defend our country, might pervert their power to the injury of their fellow citizens, the people are confirmed by the article in their right to keep and bear private arms."  Tench Coxe, Remarks on the First Part of the Amendments to the Federal Constitution. Published under the pseudonym, "A Pennsylvanian" in the Philadelphia Federal Gazette, June 18, 1789 at 2 Col. 1.
 
 Coxe forwarded his Remarks to Madison, who was at the time campaigning in New York for adoption of his BoR. Madison wrote him back and informed him that his Remarks were being published in the local papers, and he thanked Coxe by noting that his proposed amendments were "therefore already indebted to the co-operation of your pen."  James Madison, 12 Madison Papers, p. 257 (Rutland Ed. 1979) [Letter from Madison to Coxe, June 24, 1789]. 
 
 Coxe wasn't the only founding father who believed that the proposed Second Amendment recognized an individual RKBA. Here are a few more examples:
 
 "The rights of conscience, of bearing arms, of changing the government, are declared to be inherent in the people."  Fisher Ames, 1 Works of Fisher Ames, pp. 52-53 (1854) [Letter to Thomas Dwight, June 11, 1789].
 
 "Last Monday, a string of amendments were presented to the lower house; these altogether respected personal liberty. . . ."  William Grayson, 3 Patrick Henry, p. 391 (1951) [letter from Grayson to Henry, June 12, 1789] (apparently Grayson felt that his friend Patrick Henry needed the assurance of his opinion that the proposed BoR preserved individual liberty).
 
 Therefore, in light of what I suggest is an accurate rendition of "the spirit of the debates," I believe that the phrase "a well regulated militia being necessary to the SECURITY of a FREE state" is a preamble which expresses a universally accepted principle that the best way to provide for the security of a FREE state (ie. A state in which the individual citizen need not fear the tyrannical ambitions of his elected leaders) is by the employment of a well-regulated militia and the avoidance, as far as practical, of a long service professional standing army. In my opinion this assertion of a cornerstone of free government does not act to restrict the individual RKBA that is asserted in the phrase which follows in the amendment. To summarize the principle behind the militia preamble another way:
 
 "Whenever, therefore, the profession of arms becomes a distinct order in the state. . .the end of the social compact is defeated. . . .No free government was ever founded, or ever preserved its liberty, without uniting the characters of the citizen and soldier in those destined for defense of the state. . . .Such a well regulated militia, composed of freeholders, citizens and husbandman, who take up arms to preserve their property, as individuals, and their rights as freemen."  M. T. Cicero (a pseudonym), Charleston State Gazette, September 8, 1788.
 
 In addition to this, I believe that there are other clues to this individual right intention for the amendment. For example, when Madison drafted the BoR he knew that the Constitution contained, in Article I sec. 8, a provision for state authority over their militias (the authority to appoint militia officers). If Madison believed the 2nd. Amendment should merely recognize a collective "state" authority to arm their militia members free from federal interference, then he could have easily saved us much confusion by placing the amendment alongside the other recognition of state militia authority. Instead, he chose to place the right within a body of individual liberties.
 
 He also chose to use the word "people." The collective right theory would edit this specific term to have the amendment read "the right of the states." But Madison knew there was a distinct difference between the "states" and the "people" (see the 10th. Amendment, for example). If he wanted to signify a power of the states, then I believe he would never have used the word "people." 
 
 Finally, I don't believe Madison can be blamed with a typographical error, because he used the distinct phrase "right of the people" more than once, and each time it was intended to recognize an individual liberty interest. The First Amendment reads the "the right of the people peaceably to assemble...." The Second Amendment reads "the right of the people to keep and bear arms...." The Fourth Amendment reads "right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures...."  Nicholas Johnson noted this posed a difficult problem for the collective right theory; namely, that it requires an Orwellian exercise in double-think to conclude that:
 
 "[T]he term "the People" was intended to protect the rights of private individuals to assemble peaceably and petition the government in the First Amendment, was somehow transformed in the Second into a right of states, and then miraculously was returned to a right of private individuals to be secure in their persons, houses, papers and effects in the Fourth Amendment." Nicholas J. Johnson, Shots Across No Man's Land: A Response to Handgun Control, Inc.'s, Richard Aborn, 22 Fordham Urb. L.J. 448 (1995).
 
 I myself am not capable of such blind mental gymnastics. Therefore, I believe that the Second Amendment was drafted to recognize an individual citizen's RKBA. The DOES NOT mean that the right must be absolute. It must of necessity be subject to some rational limitation, but that is another issue for another day. In the meantime, I reject the collective right theory for what I believe it to be: a fraudulent twisting of the plain language of an individual right for the purpose of justifying a policy of individual disarmament.
